title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act is titled the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments not used on other healthcare programs. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments not used on other healthcare programs. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a State reinsurance program to meet the requirements. The State must operate a reinsurance program by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. States without a high-risk pool must establish a reinsurance program to meet requirements. The State's operation of the reinsurance program is treated as a qualified high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. The State must operate a reinsurance program funded by State premium assessments. If the program is in strong fiscal health, it is deemed to meet requirements. The reinsurance program is treated as a qualified high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. A "qualified State reinsurance program" is defined as a program operated by a State that provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage in the small group market. The program can operate on a prospective or retrospective basis and must meet standards established by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and approved by the State Insurance Commissioner. A qualified State reinsurance program can provide reinsurance on a prospective or retrospective basis, protecting health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending and catastrophic costs. It must satisfy HIPAA requirements and be deemed a qualified high-risk pool under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. A qualifying State high-risk pool must meet specific requirements. A qualifying State high risk pool must provide two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account, have stable funding, eliminate waiting lists, and cover individuals who face a 24-month disability waiting period. The high risk pool must provide coverage for individuals who would be eligible for Medicare during a disability waiting period, limit premiums to 150% of the average standard risk rates, conduct education and outreach initiatives, and offer preventive services and disease management. The high risk pool must provide coverage for preventive services and disease management for chronic diseases. Only citizens and nationals of the United States are eligible to participate in the pool. Verification of citizenship or alien qualification is required for participation. As a condition for receiving funds, States must certify that applicants for coverage in the high risk pool provide documentation of citizenship or nationality. The Secretary will maintain records to verify citizenship or nationality only once per individual. Starting January 1, 2015, a pool must meet specific criteria to qualify as a high risk pool. As of January 1, 2015, a pool must meet specific criteria to qualify as a high risk pool under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may waive requirements for new programs, and funding of $15 billion is allocated for fiscal years 2015 through 2024. Funding of $15 billion is allocated for fiscal years 2015 through 2024, with an additional $10 billion for fiscal years 2020 through 2024. Definitions for "health insurance coverage" and "health insurance issuer" are provided in section 2791 of the Public Health Service Act. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" refers to the qualified high risk pool under section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" refers to the qualified high risk pool under section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined under the State high risk pool using actuarial techniques to reflect anticipated claims and expenses. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia. It involves individuals in the insurance market, established using actuarial techniques, reflecting anticipated claims and expenses.
